questions.text: Secondary glaucoma associated with angle recession is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Concussion injury Angle recession glaucoma is a type of secondary glaucoma that occurs due to trauma, typically following a concussion injury to the eye. In a concussion injury, blunt trauma can cause damage to the anterior chamber angle structures, particularly a tear between the longitudinal and circular fibers of the ciliary muscle. This results in angle recession, which may not cause immediate issues but can later lead to impaired aqueous humor outflow and elevated intraocular pressure, ultimately causing glaucoma. Incorrect Answers: A. Radiation injury: Radiation injury to the eye can cause complications like cataracts, retinopathy, and optic neuropathy, but it is not typically associated with angle recession or secondary glaucoma caused by angle damage. C. Perforating injury: A perforating injury can lead to secondary glaucoma through mechanisms such as hyphema, inflammation, or scarring, but it does not typically result in angle recession, as the trauma is direct and penetrating rather than blunt. D. Chemical injury: Chemical injuries to the eye cause damage to the cornea, conjunctiva, and other ocular structures but do not lead to angle recession. Secondary glaucoma in this scenario is more likely due to scarring or inflammation in the anterior chamber.

questions.text: Hypersecretory glaucoma is seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Epidemic dropsy Hypersecretory glaucoma is a condition where there is an increased production of aqueous humor, leading to elevated intraocular pressure. It is commonly associated with epidemic dropsy, which is caused by the consumption of adulterated mustard oil contaminated with Sanguinarine toxin. This toxin leads to widespread vascular leakage, inflammation, and increased secretion of aqueous humor, resulting in secondary glaucoma with a hypersecretory mechanism. Incorrect Answers: B. Marfan's syndrome: Marfan's syndrome is a connective tissue disorder that may lead to lens dislocation (ectopia lentis) and secondary glaucoma due to lens-related issues or angle abnormalities. However, it is not associated with hypersecretion of aqueous humor. C. Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome: Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome is another connective tissue disorder that can cause ocular complications like keratoconus, blue sclera, and glaucoma due to structural abnormalities. It is not linked to hypersecretory mechanisms. D. Pseudoxanthoma elasticum: This condition affects elastic fibers in the body, leading to systemic vascular issues and retinal complications like angioid streaks, but it does not cause hypersecretory glaucoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a diagnostic criteria of Vogt’s triad in chronic angle closure glaucoma:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Goniosynechiae Vogt’s triad is a set of clinical features commonly associated with chronic angle closure glaucoma. The triad includes: Iris atrophy – The iris undergoes structural damage due to chronic pressure elevation. Glaucomflecken – These are anterior subcapsular lens opacities caused by lens epithelial cell necrosis due to intermittent high intraocular pressure. Pigment dispersion – Pigment from the posterior layer of the iris is released into the aqueous humor and deposited on various structures, including the trabecular meshwork. Goniosynechiae, which refers to adhesions between the iris and the angle structures, is not a component of Vogt’s triad, though it is commonly observed in chronic angle closure glaucoma. It is a structural finding detected on gonioscopy but not part of the diagnostic Vogt’s triad. Incorrect Answers: B. Iris atrophy: This is a key feature of Vogt’s triad caused by ischemic damage to the iris from intermittent angle closure and elevated intraocular pressure. C. Glaucomflecken: Glaucomflecken are part of the Vogt’s triad and represent necrotic changes in the lens due to acute or chronic pressure elevation. D. Pigment dispersion: Pigment dispersion is a diagnostic feature of Vogt’s triad and results from mechanical rubbing of the iris against the lens or zonules, leading to pigment release.

questions.text: Raised episcleral venous pressure cases glaucoma in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Sturge-Weber syndrome In Sturge-Weber syndrome, a congenital condition associated with facial port-wine stains and vascular malformations, raised episcleral venous pressure can lead to secondary glaucoma. The abnormal venous drainage in the episcleral veins due to the vascular malformations causes increased resistance to the outflow of aqueous humor, leading to elevated intraocular pressure (IOP) and glaucoma. Incorrect Answers: A. Pseudoexfoliation glaucoma: Pseudoexfoliation glaucoma is caused by the deposition of exfoliative material on the anterior segment structures, particularly the trabecular meshwork, which impairs aqueous humor outflow. It is unrelated to episcleral venous pressure. B. Phacomorphic glaucoma: Phacomorphic glaucoma is a type of secondary angle-closure glaucoma caused by an intumescent (swollen) lens that obstructs the flow of aqueous humor and causes angle closure. Episcleral venous pressure is not involved. C. Neovascular glaucoma: Neovascular glaucoma is due to the formation of abnormal new blood vessels on the iris and trabecular meshwork, often secondary to conditions like diabetes or retinal vein occlusion. It results from vascular obstruction, not raised episcleral venous pressure.

questions.text: Earliest visual field defect in primary open-angle glaucoma is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Scotoma in Bjerrum area The earliest visual field defect in primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) typically occurs in the Bjerrum area, which is an arcuate region extending from 10° to 20° from fixation above or below the horizontal meridian. The defect often begins as a localized depression or small scotoma in this region and can progress to form an arcuate scotoma. This area is particularly vulnerable to damage due to the arrangement of nerve fibers in the retina, which are affected early in glaucoma. Incorrect Answers: A. Seidel's scotoma: A Seidel's scotoma is an extension of the blind spot and is seen in more advanced stages of glaucoma, not as an early defect. B. Arcuate scotoma: While an arcuate scotoma is a classic visual field defect in glaucoma, it typically develops later in the disease as the Bjerrum scotoma progresses and coalesces with other defects. C. Roenne's nasal steps: Nasal steps occur due to loss of nerve fibers near the horizontal raphe and are common in glaucoma, but they usually appear slightly later than initial scotomas in the Bjerrum area.

questions.text: Side-effect of Latanoprost is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Iris hyperpigmentation Latanoprost, a prostaglandin analog used to lower intraocular pressure in glaucoma, has a well-documented side effect of iris hyperpigmentation. This occurs due to increased melanin production in iris melanocytes, particularly in individuals with mixed-colored or lighter-colored irises. The pigmentation change is typically permanent but does not cause functional vision problems. Incorrect Answers: A. Visual blur: While transient blurred vision can occur with some eye drops, it is not a significant or common side effect of Latanoprost. B. Adenochrome deposition: Adenochrome deposition in the conjunctiva is a side effect associated with epinephrine-containing medications, not prostaglandin analogs like Latanoprost. D. Iris hypopigmentation: Latanoprost causes hyperpigmentation, not hypopigmentation. Hypopigmentation is not a recognized side effect of this medication.

questions.text: Treatment of choice in acute congestive glaucoma:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Laser iridotomy In acute congestive glaucoma (acute angle-closure glaucoma), the treatment of choice is laser iridotomy. This procedure creates a small hole in the peripheral iris, allowing the aqueous humor to bypass the pupillary block and flow directly from the posterior to the anterior chamber, thereby reducing intraocular pressure (IOP). It is a definitive treatment that addresses the underlying mechanism of angle closure and prevents recurrence in the affected and fellow eye. Incorrect Answers: A. Pilocarpine: While pilocarpine can be used in acute angle-closure glaucoma to constrict the pupil and open the drainage angle, its efficacy is limited in the presence of severe IOP elevation. Additionally, pilocarpine may not work well when the iris is ischemic, which is common in acute congestive glaucoma. B. Trabeculectomy: Trabeculectomy is a surgical procedure used in chronic glaucoma to lower IOP by creating a new drainage pathway. It is not the first-line treatment for acute congestive glaucoma, as laser iridotomy is less invasive and more effective for addressing the acute condition. D. Trabeculoplasty: Trabeculoplasty is a laser procedure used to treat open-angle glaucoma by improving trabecular outflow. It is not effective in acute angle-closure glaucoma because the drainage angle is physically obstructed.

questions.text: Coloured halos are seen in all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Acute anterior uveitis Coloured halos occur due to diffraction of light caused by deposits, swelling, or edema in the eye. They are typically associated with conditions affecting the cornea or lens. Incorrect Options: A. Mucopurulent conjunctivitis: Coloured halos can occur due to mucous discharge or purulent debris on the corneal surface, which scatters light and creates a halo effect. C. Intumescent cataract: In this condition, lens changes, including swelling and water absorption, can lead to diffraction of light, producing coloured halos around lights. D. Glaucoma: Coloured halos are a hallmark of acute congestive glaucoma, caused by corneal edema due to elevated intraocular pressure (IOP).

questions.text: Which examination is of least value in open-angle glaucoma:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Indirect ophthalmoscopy Open-angle glaucoma primarily involves progressive damage to the optic nerve head and loss of peripheral vision due to increased intraocular pressure (IOP). The most valuable examinations focus on assessing the IOP, visual field, and optic nerve. Indirect ophthalmoscopy, while useful for examining the peripheral retina and vitreous, has limited utility in evaluating open-angle glaucoma. Examination Techniques: A. Tonometry: This is highly valuable in glaucoma as it measures intraocular pressure (IOP), a critical factor in the pathogenesis and management of open-angle glaucoma. B. Perimetry: This is essential for detecting visual field defects, which are the hallmark of glaucoma. It helps monitor disease progression and the effectiveness of treatment. C. Indirect ophthalmoscopy: Indirect ophthalmoscopy is of limited value in open-angle glaucoma because it provides a wide-field view of the retina but does not allow detailed evaluation of the optic nerve head, which is critical in glaucoma assessment. D. Direct ophthalmoscopy: While not as comprehensive as modern imaging techniques, direct ophthalmoscopy allows a detailed view of the optic nerve head, enabling the detection of glaucomatous changes like cupping.

questions.text: All the following anatomical changes will predispose to primary angle closure glaucoma; except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Thick cornea Primary angle-closure glaucoma occurs when the anterior chamber angle is narrowed or closed, impeding the outflow of aqueous humor and leading to increased intraocular pressure. Several anatomical factors predispose to this condition by contributing to a crowded anterior segment. Anatomical Changes That Predispose to Primary Angle-Closure Glaucoma: A. Small cornea: A smaller cornea is often associated with a smaller anterior segment and shallower anterior chamber, increasing the risk of angle closure. C. Anterior chamber shallow: A shallow anterior chamber is one of the primary risk factors for angle closure because it reduces the space between the iris and cornea, predisposing to pupillary block and angle closure. D. Short axial length of the eyeball: A shorter axial length is commonly seen in hyperopic eyes, which have smaller anterior segments and shallow anterior chambers, increasing the risk of angle closure.

questions.text: Normally in right eye, the peripheral field of vision is usually least in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) In the upward direction The peripheral field of vision refers to the area of vision outside of the central visual field. It is generally less extensive in certain directions due to the anatomical configuration of the eye and its surrounding structures. In the right eye, the peripheral visual field is usually least in the upward direction. This is due to the position of the eyelid, brow, and the more limited range of upward gaze compared to other directions. As a result, the visual field is slightly more restricted upward than in other directions. Incorrect Answers: A. On the left side (nasally): The visual field extends more to the nasal side due to the way the retina is organized. The temporal fields from each eye overlap in the central region, allowing for good peripheral vision on the left (nasal) side of the right eye. B. In the downward direction: The downward peripheral visual field is relatively expansive. The anatomical structures like the lower eyelid and the alignment of the eye allow a broader visual range downward. D. On the right side (temporal): The right (temporal) side of the visual field is generally broad and unobstructed, contributing to the wide peripheral field.

questions.text: A patient of glaucoma develops blepharoconjunctivitis after instilling some antiglaucoma drugs. Which of the following drug can be responsible for it:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Timolol Timolol, a beta-blocker used in the treatment of glaucoma, is commonly associated with blepharoconjunctivitis, which is inflammation of the eyelids (blepharitis) and conjunctiva (conjunctivitis). This side effect can occur due to the preservatives in the medication, such as benzalkonium chloride, which is often included in topical glaucoma medications. The preservatives can cause irritation and allergic reactions in some individuals, leading to blepharoconjunctivitis. Incorrect Answers: B. Latanoprost: Latanoprost is a prostaglandin analog used in glaucoma treatment. While it can cause side effects like iris pigmentation and eyelash changes, it is not typically associated with blepharoconjunctivitis. However, it can cause other ocular side effects like eye irritation or conjunctival hyperemia. C. Dorzolamide: Dorzolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor. While it can cause ocular side effects such as burning or stinging on instillation, it is not as commonly associated with blepharoconjunctivitis compared to beta-blockers like timolol. D. Pilocarpine: Pilocarpine, an acetylcholine agonist, can cause side effects like pupillary constriction, accommodation problems, and eye irritation, but it is less likely to cause blepharoconjunctivitis compared to timolol.

questions.text: You have been referred a middle-aged patient to rule out open angle glaucoma. Which of the following findings will help in the diagnosis:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cupping of the disc Cupping of the optic disc is a key diagnostic feature of open-angle glaucoma. It occurs due to damage to the optic nerve fibers as a result of elevated intraocular pressure (IOP). The increased pressure causes a loss of neural tissue at the optic nerve head, creating a characteristic cup that is larger than the normal physiological cup. In open-angle glaucoma, the cup-to-disc ratio is typically increased, which can be observed on fundoscopy. This is one of the primary signs that help in diagnosing glaucoma. Incorrect Answers: B. Depth of anterior chamber: While a shallow anterior chamber can predispose to angle-closure glaucoma, it is not typically relevant in open-angle glaucoma, which is characterized by a normal anterior chamber depth and the obstruction occurring at the level of the trabecular meshwork rather than the angle. C. Visual acuity and refractive error: These are important for general eye health but are not typically affected early in open-angle glaucoma. In fact, visual acuity often remains normal until late in the disease, while refractive error does not play a role in diagnosing glaucoma. D. Angle of the anterior chamber: The anterior chamber angle is usually open in open-angle glaucoma, hence this finding is not useful for diagnosing it. A narrow or closed angle is typically seen in angle-closure glaucoma, not open-angle glaucoma.

questions.text: In a hypertensive patient with glaucoma, which of the following is not used
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Dipivefrine In a hypertensive patient with glaucoma, Dipivefrine is typically not recommended because it is a prodrug of epinephrine and has alpha and beta-adrenergic effects. These adrenergic effects can potentially increase blood pressure, which is a concern for patients with hypertension. Dipivefrine works by increasing aqueous humor outflow but may exacerbate hypertension due to its systemic vasoconstrictive effects. Incorrect Answers: B. Beta blockers: Beta-blockers (e.g., timolol) are commonly used to reduce intraocular pressure (IOP) in glaucoma patients. In hypertensive patients, beta-blockers are often used both for glaucoma and to control blood pressure, as they lower IOP by reducing aqueous humor production. C. Alpha agonist: Alpha agonists (e.g., brimonidine) are used in glaucoma management to reduce IOP by decreasing aqueous humor production and increasing uveoscleral outflow. These drugs are safe for use in hypertensive patients and do not typically raise blood pressure. D. Laser trabeculoplasty: Laser trabeculoplasty (e.g., argon laser trabeculoplasty, selective laser trabeculoplasty) is a procedure that can be used to treat open-angle glaucoma by improving the outflow of aqueous humor. It is safe for hypertensive patients as it directly affects the drainage angle and does not influence systemic blood pressure.

questions.text: All are contact type of applanation tonometer except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Pulsair Applanation tonometry measures intraocular pressure (IOP) by flattening a small area of the cornea. Most applanation tonometers come in contact with the eye, except for the Pulsair tonometer. Contact Applanation Tonometers: A. Tonopen: The Tonopen is a handheld, portable, contact applanation tonometer that touches the cornea to measure IOP. It is commonly used in clinical settings and is ideal for patients who have difficulty sitting still or when using other tonometers is challenging. B. Perkins: The Perkins tonometer is a portable, contact applanation tonometer. It is similar to the Goldmann tonometer but can be used in more varied patient positions, such as sitting or lying down. D. Goldmann: The Goldmann applanation tonometer is the gold standard for IOP measurement and is a contact tonometer. It is typically used in a slit-lamp examination and requires direct contact with the cornea.

questions.text: Antimetabolite used in filteration surgery is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Mitomycin C Mitomycin C is an antimetabolite that is commonly used in filtration surgery (e.g., trabeculectomy) for glaucoma. It is used as an adjuvant to prevent scarring and fibrosis of the surgical wound by inhibiting the synthesis of DNA, which helps in maintaining the function of the filtration bleb. This reduces the likelihood of postoperative failure due to excessive scarring. Incorrect Answers: A. Cyclophosphamide: Cyclophosphamide is an alkylating agent used in cancer treatment and immunosuppressive therapy, but it is not typically used in glaucoma surgery or as an antimetabolite for filtration surgery. B. Cyclosporin: Cyclosporin is an immunosuppressive drug that is used primarily to prevent organ transplant rejection, but it is not used as an antimetabolite in filtration surgery for glaucoma. D. Tacrolimus: Tacrolimus is also an immunosuppressive agent similar to cyclosporin, used to prevent organ rejection. Like cyclosporin, it is not used as an antimetabolite in filtration surgery for glaucoma.

questions.text: A male patient with a history of hypemature cataract presents with a 2 day history of ciliary congestion, photophobia, blurring of vision and on examination has a deep anterior chamber in the right eye. The left eye is normal. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Phacolytic glaucoma Phacolytic glaucoma is a type of secondary glaucoma that occurs when a hypermature cataract (often a mature or intumescent cataract) undergoes spontaneous rupture or leakage of the lens proteins into the aqueous humor. This can lead to an inflammatory response and blockage of the trabecular meshwork, causing an increase in intraocular pressure (IOP). The patient's symptoms — including ciliary congestion, photophobia, blurring of vision, and a deep anterior chamber — suggest an inflammatory process in the eye, with the right eye being affected. The deep anterior chamber indicates that the cause is more likely to be a posterior lens rupture or leakage, which is characteristic of phacolytic glaucoma. Incorrect Answers: A. Phacomorphic glaucoma: This occurs when a mature or intumescent cataract causes anterior chamber angle closure due to lens enlargement. It is typically associated with a shallow anterior chamber and does not usually present with a deep anterior chamber like in this case. B. Phacotoxic glaucoma: This type of glaucoma occurs when the lens material is released into the eye following cataract surgery, leading to toxic damage to the trabecular meshwork and elevated IOP. This condition is usually associated with surgical trauma and not the spontaneous rupture of a hypermature cataract. C. Phacoanaphylactic glaucoma: This occurs when lens material (proteins) provoke a delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction, leading to inflammation and elevated IOP. It often involves a strong allergic response and is typically more acute and inflammatory. It is less likely in the absence of a history of trauma or surgery.

questions.text: All are side-effects of pilocarpine except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Folliculosis Pilocarpine is a muscarinic agonist commonly used to treat glaucoma by reducing intraocular pressure through increased aqueous humor outflow. While it has several known side effects, folliculosis (the formation of lymphoid follicles in the conjunctiva) is not one of them. Known Side Effects of Pilocarpine: A. Shallow anterior chamber: Pilocarpine causes pupil constriction (miosis), which can lead to an anterior chamber that becomes shallow in some individuals, especially if the angle is already narrow. This can increase the risk of angle-closure glaucoma. C. Posterior synechiae: Pilocarpine can cause the formation of posterior synechiae, which are adhesions between the iris and the lens due to the intense constriction of the pupil. D. Punctal stenosis: Pilocarpine can lead to punctal stenosis (narrowing of the tear drainage ducts), which can result in tear drainage issues and cause dryness or irritation in the eye.

questions.text: Blind spot of eye due to
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Optic disc The blind spot in the eye occurs at the optic disc, which is the point where the optic nerve exits the retina. The optic disc lacks photoreceptor cells (rods and cones), so it cannot detect light or form visual images. As a result, this area of the retina is insensitive to light and creates a "blind spot" in the visual field. This spot is present in both eyes, but the brain typically compensates by filling in the missing information from the surrounding visual cues, so we are usually unaware of it in our daily vision. Incorrect Answers: B. 2mm away from disc: The blind spot is located at the optic disc itself, not 2mm away from it. This is not where the blind spot occurs. C. Yellow spot: The yellow spot, or macula lutea, is responsible for central vision and is rich in cones that allow for sharp, detailed vision. The macula does not contribute to the blind spot. D. Corneo-scleral function: This refers to the structural function of the cornea and sclera in maintaining the shape and integrity of the eye. It is unrelated to the blind spot, which is due to the absence of photoreceptor cells at the optic disc.

questions.text: Increased intraocular tension is seen in all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Phthisis bulbi Phthisis bulbi is a condition characterized by the shrinkage and atrophy of the eyeball, usually due to chronic inflammation or severe trauma. In this condition, the eye typically has low intraocular pressure (IOP) due to the loss of intraocular contents and the collapse of the eye structure, not increased IOP. Incorrect Answers: A. Epidemic dropsy: Epidemic dropsy is caused by Sanguinarine toxicity from contaminated mustard oil and can lead to increased IOP due to inflammation and raised episcleral venous pressure. This can cause secondary glaucoma. B. Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO): CRVO can cause increased IOP as a result of retinal venous congestion and the associated secondary glaucomatous changes that occur in some cases of CRVO, particularly in neovascular glaucoma. C. Malignant melanoma: Malignant melanoma of the eye, particularly when it affects the uveal tract, can lead to increased IOP due to tumor-related blockage of the aqueous humor outflow or secondary glaucoma.

questions.text: Neovascular glaucoma is not seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Pseudoexfoliation Neovascular glaucoma occurs when new, abnormal blood vessels grow on the iris and in the angle of the anterior chamber, obstructing the normal outflow of aqueous humor and leading to increased intraocular pressure (IOP). This condition is typically caused by ischemic events or conditions that lead to hypoxia in the eye, stimulating angiogenesis (formation of new blood vessels). Conditions Associated with Neovascular Glaucoma: A. Ocular ischemic syndrome: This syndrome results from reduced blood flow to the eye, often due to carotid artery occlusion, leading to hypoxia and the subsequent development of neovascularization in the retina and iris. This can lead to neovascular glaucoma. B. Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO): CRVO can cause retinal ischemia, leading to neovascularization in the retina and iris, which can result in neovascular glaucoma. D. Diabetes mellitus: In diabetic patients, especially with diabetic retinopathy, there is often retinal ischemia, leading to neovascularization. This can cause neovascular glaucoma due to the growth of new, abnormal blood vessels obstructing the drainage angle.

questions.text: Treatment of choice for congenital glaucoma is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Goniotomy Congenital glaucoma, also known as primary congenital glaucoma (PCG), is a rare form of glaucoma that occurs due to improper development of the anterior chamber angle, leading to impaired drainage of aqueous humor and increased intraocular pressure (IOP). Goniotomy is the treatment of choice for congenital glaucoma. This surgical procedure involves making an incision in the trabecular meshwork to improve aqueous humor outflow, which lowers IOP. It is commonly performed in infants and young children diagnosed with congenital glaucoma. Incorrect Answers: A. Trephining: Trephining is a procedure generally used for creating a surgical opening in the cornea, often used in cases of corneal transplants or perforated corneal ulcers, but it is not the preferred treatment for congenital glaucoma. C. Scheie's operation: Scheie's operation is a type of surgery used to treat open-angle glaucoma in adults by creating an opening in the trabecular meshwork, but it is not typically used for congenital glaucoma. D. Cyclodialysis: Cyclodialysis is a procedure used in certain types of glaucoma, particularly angle-closure glaucoma, where a communication is created between the anterior chamber and the ciliary body to reduce IOP. It is not used for treating congenital glaucoma.

questions.text: The following are recognised side effects of various antiglaucoma therapies except:-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Betaxolol causes bronchoconstriction Betaxolol is a cardioselective beta-blocker, meaning it primarily targets beta-1 adrenergic receptors in the heart rather than beta-2 receptors in the lungs. As a result, it has minimal effect on the lungs and is less likely to cause bronchoconstriction compared to non-selective beta-blockers like timolol, which affect both beta-1 and beta-2 receptors and can potentially cause bronchoconstriction, particularly in patients with asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Hence, bronchoconstriction is not a recognized side effect of betaxolol. Incorrect Answers: A. Pilocarpine causes myopia: Pilocarpine, a muscarinic agonist, induces pupil constriction (miosis) and accommodation. In individuals with existing myopia or long-term use, this can lead to accommodative spasm, which can cause temporary myopia (nearsightedness). Hence, myopia is a recognized side effect of pilocarpine. B. Adrenaline causes cystoid macular oedema: Adrenaline (epinephrine), when used in glaucoma treatment, has alpha and beta-adrenergic effects, and one of its ocular side effects is the development of cystoid macular edema (CME), particularly in patients with a history of cataract surgery or diabetes. Therefore, CME is a known side effect of adrenaline. D. Acetazolamide causes renal stones: Acetazolamide, a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, can alter the balance of electrolytes and increase the excretion of calcium in the urine. This can lead to the formation of renal stones (calcium phosphate stones) as a side effect. Thus, renal stones are a recognized side effect of acetazolamide.

questions.text: All are true regarding malignant glaucoma except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Does not occur if there is a functioning trabeculectomy Malignant glaucoma, also known as inverse glaucoma, is a rare and severe form of glaucoma that often occurs as a post-operative complication following cataract surgery or trabeculectomy. It is characterized by high intraocular pressure (IOP) despite an open or functioning anterior chamber angle, caused by an abnormal accumulation of aqueous humor in the posterior segment, resulting in a shallow anterior chamber. Treatment typically involves vitrectomy to relieve the pressure by allowing aqueous humor to flow more freely. Incorrect Answers: A. Is a post-operative complication: This is true. Malignant glaucoma is a known post-operative complication, particularly after cataract surgery or trabeculectomy, and can develop when there is improper aqueous humor dynamics post-surgery. C. Is also known as inverse glaucoma: This is true. Malignant glaucoma is sometimes referred to as inverse glaucoma because it involves the abnormal accumulation of aqueous humor in the posterior segment rather than the anterior chamber, which is the opposite of how typical glaucoma manifests. D. Can be relieved by vitrectomy: This is true. Vitrectomy is one of the most effective treatments for malignant glaucoma. The procedure helps by allowing the aqueous humor to bypass the anterior segment, relieving the increased intraocular pressure.

questions.text: Pain in absolute glaucoma is best relieved by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Cyclocryotherapy Absolute glaucoma refers to a condition where the intraocular pressure (IOP) is extremely high, often in a blind eye that no longer responds to medical therapy. The pain associated with absolute glaucoma is typically due to ischemic damage and elevated IOP. One of the most effective ways to relieve this pain is cyclocryotherapy, a procedure where cryotherapy (freezing) is applied to the ciliary body to decrease aqueous humor production and lower IOP. This procedure can provide significant relief from pain and prevent further complications in the affected eye. Incorrect Answers: A. Retrobulbar injection of alcohol: Retrobulbar injection of alcohol is sometimes used to reduce pain in certain ocular conditions, including those with severe pain from an eye with no visual potential. However, it is not the first-line treatment for pain relief in absolute glaucoma, and its effects are less predictable than cyclocryotherapy. B. Analgesics: While analgesics (pain relievers) may provide temporary relief from the discomfort of absolute glaucoma, they do not address the underlying cause of the pain, which is elevated IOP and the inability to drain aqueous humor. They are used for symptomatic relief but are not effective in resolving the root cause of the pain. D. Trabeculectomy: Trabeculectomy is a surgical procedure typically used to treat open-angle glaucoma or angle-closure glaucoma by creating a new drainage pathway for aqueous humor. However, it is not indicated for pain relief in absolute glaucoma, as the damage to the eye is often irreversible, and the eye has usually lost its ability to function in a meaningful way.

questions.text: Campimetry is used to measure
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Field charting Campimetry is a type of visual field testing used to measure the field of vision or peripheral vision of a patient. It helps in detecting any visual field defects or loss of peripheral vision, which is crucial for diagnosing conditions such as glaucoma, retinal diseases, and neurological disorders. The term "field charting" refers to the process of mapping out the visual field to assess any abnormalities or areas of vision loss. Incorrect Answers: A. Squint: Squint (or strabismus) refers to the misalignment of the eyes, where the eyes do not look in the same direction at the same time. While some forms of vision testing may be used in the evaluation of squint, campimetry is not used to diagnose or measure squint directly. B. Angle of anterior chamber: The angle of the anterior chamber (which is important in conditions like angle-closure glaucoma) is typically measured using techniques like gonioscopy, not campimetry. Campimetry assesses the visual field, not the anatomical structures. C. Pattern of retina: The pattern of the retina can be evaluated with fundoscopy or optical coherence tomography (OCT). Campimetry, on the other hand, assesses the visual field, not the retinal pattern.

questions.text: All of the following conditions can produce NVG except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Keratoconus Neovascular glaucoma (NVG) is a type of secondary glaucoma characterized by the growth of new blood vessels in the iris and trabecular meshwork, which leads to a blockage in the aqueous humor drainage system and an increase in intraocular pressure (IOP). The conditions that can produce NVG generally involve retinal ischemia or conditions that cause poor blood flow to the retina, leading to the release of angiogenic factors that stimulate new vessel growth. Conditions that Can Produce NVG: A. Periphlebitis retinae: This condition, also known as retinal vein occlusion, particularly in the form of central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO), can lead to retinal ischemia. This ischemia triggers the formation of new blood vessels in the retina and the iris, causing NVG. B. CRVO (Central Retinal Vein Occlusion): CRVO is a major cause of retinal ischemia, which can trigger neovascularization and eventually lead to NVG. It is one of the classic conditions that cause NVG. C. DM (Diabetes Mellitus): Diabetic retinopathy is a leading cause of retinal ischemia and neovascularization. When the retinal blood vessels are damaged due to chronic hyperglycemia, it leads to neovascular glaucoma.

questions.text: The drug of choice in acute angle-closure glaucoma is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Mannitol The treatment of acute angle-closure glaucoma (a medical emergency) involves rapidly lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) to prevent damage to the optic nerve. The drug of choice in this situation is mannitol, which is an osmotic diuretic. Mannitol works by drawing fluid out of the eye and reducing IOP quickly. It is typically administered intravenously to reduce the volume of aqueous humor in the eye, providing rapid relief from elevated IOP. Incorrect Answers: A. Timolol maleate: Timolol is a beta-blocker used in the chronic management of glaucoma, particularly open-angle glaucoma, to lower IOP by reducing aqueous humor production. However, it is not the drug of choice in acute angle-closure glaucoma because it does not provide rapid or effective enough reduction in IOP in this emergency situation. B. Phospholine iodide: Phospholine iodide (echothiophate) is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that can help lower IOP by increasing the outflow of aqueous humor. However, it is not used in acute angle-closure glaucoma due to its slower onset of action and potential for causing side effects, particularly in acute emergencies. C. Clonidine: Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used to lower blood pressure and may have a modest effect on IOP. However, it is not the preferred choice in acute angle-closure glaucoma. It does not work fast enough or as effectively as osmotic agents like mannitol in acute situations.

questions.text: A 5 year old child presents with large cornea, lacrimation and photophobia. The probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Congenital glaucoma The symptoms of large cornea, lacrimation, and photophobia in a 5-year-old child are characteristic of congenital glaucoma. This condition is caused by a developmental defect in the drainage system of the eye, leading to increased intraocular pressure (IOP). The increased pressure can result in buphthalmos (enlargement of the eyeball) and a larger cornea. Additionally, the irritation caused by the elevated IOP leads to symptoms like lacrimation (tearing) and photophobia (sensitivity to light). Incorrect Answers: A. Megalocornea: Megalocornea refers to an abnormally large cornea but typically does not present with lacrimation and photophobia. It is generally a non-glaucomatous condition and does not involve elevated IOP or the associated symptoms seen in congenital glaucoma. C. Congenital cataract: Congenital cataracts may cause visual disturbances and sometimes a white reflex in the eye (leukocoria), but they do not typically present with a large cornea, lacrimation, and photophobia. These are more characteristic of congenital glaucoma. D. Anterior uveitis: Anterior uveitis is an inflammatory condition that can cause photophobia, but it does not typically cause a large cornea. It can cause pain, redness, and vision problems, but the large cornea seen in this case is more consistent with congenital glaucoma.

questions.text: Mild-dilated pupil, not reacting to light is seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Acute Congestive Glaucoma In acute congestive glaucoma (also known as acute angle-closure glaucoma), a mildly dilated pupil that does not react to light is one of the classic signs. This occurs because the iris is pushed forward, which leads to angle closure and pupillary block, resulting in a mid-dilated, non-reactive pupil. This non-reactive pupil is due to the increased intraocular pressure (IOP), which impairs the normal functioning of the pupillary sphincter. Other associated symptoms include pain, blurred vision, nausea, and vomiting. Incorrect Answers: B. Chronic Congestive Glaucoma: In chronic congestive glaucoma (often associated with open-angle glaucoma), the pupil is typically reactive. The condition develops gradually, and the pupil usually remains normal or slightly sluggish, but it doesn't show the significant dilation and non-reactivity seen in acute angle-closure glaucoma. C. Open Angle Glaucoma: Open-angle glaucoma typically presents with gradual loss of peripheral vision and has no acute changes in pupil size or reactivity. The pupil usually reacts to light unless there's significant optic nerve damage. This condition does not cause a mildly dilated, non-reactive pupil. D. Congenital Glaucoma: Congenital glaucoma usually presents in infants with corneal enlargement and buphthalmos. The pupil in congenital glaucoma may be larger or show other abnormalities but is typically reactive to light. Non-reactivity is not a characteristic sign.
