questions.text: Tonography helps to determine
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Facility of outflow of aqueous Tonography is a diagnostic test used to measure the facility of outflow of aqueous humor from the eye. It helps to assess how efficiently the aqueous humor is draining from the anterior chamber through the trabecular meshwork and the outflow pathway. The procedure involves measuring the intraocular pressure (IOP) over a period of time after a small amount of pressure is applied to the eye. The results help determine whether the drainage system is functioning properly and can identify conditions such as glaucoma where aqueous humor outflow is impaired. Incorrect Answers: A. Rate of formation of aqueous: While tonography provides information about the outflow of aqueous humor, it does not directly measure the rate of formation of aqueous humor. Measurement of aqueous humor production is typically done through other methods, like fluorophotometry. C. The levels of intraocular pressure at different times: Tonography does not directly measure intraocular pressure at different times; it measures the outflow facility, which is related to changes in pressure. Intraocular pressure measurements are usually done through methods like tonometry. D. None of the above: This is incorrect because facility of outflow is a key aspect of tonography, so option B is the correct answer.

questions.text: A patient of glaucoma with bronchial asthma presents to the emergency with status asthmaticus. Causative agent might have been:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Levobunolol Levobunolol is a non-selective beta-blocker used to treat glaucoma by reducing intraocular pressure (IOP). However, non-selective beta-blockers can block beta-2 receptors in the lungs, which can lead to bronchoconstriction. In patients with bronchial asthma, this can precipitate status asthmaticus, a severe and potentially life-threatening asthma attack. Therefore, Levobunolol can be a causative agent in this case. Incorrect Answers: A. Pilocarpine: Pilocarpine is a muscarinic agonist used to treat glaucoma by increasing aqueous humor outflow. It primarily acts on the pupil and ciliary muscle and is not known to cause bronchoconstriction or exacerbate asthma. B. Betaxolol: Betaxolol is a cardioselective beta-blocker that primarily affects beta-1 receptors in the heart and has minimal effect on beta-2 receptors in the lungs. It is less likely to cause bronchoconstriction or worsen asthma compared to non-selective beta-blockers. D. Epinephrine: Epinephrine is a sympathomimetic drug that relaxes bronchial smooth muscle and is commonly used to treat acute asthma exacerbations. It is unlikely to cause bronchoconstriction; in fact, it helps to relieve bronchospasm.

questions.text: Ring scotoma is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Retinitis pigmentosa A ring scotoma is a type of visual field defect characterized by a ring-shaped area of vision loss, typically seen around the central vision. This type of scotoma is most commonly associated with retinitis pigmentosa (RP), a hereditary retinal disorder that causes progressive peripheral vision loss and leads to the formation of ring scotomas around the central vision. As the disease progresses, the ring scotoma may expand, and central vision may eventually be affected. Incorrect Answers: A. Panophthalmitis: Panophthalmitis refers to a severe, widespread inflammation of all layers of the eye, often following infection or trauma. While it can cause significant vision problems, ring scotomas are not a typical feature. The vision loss in panophthalmitis is usually due to inflammation and infection rather than a ring-shaped defect. C. Sympathetic ophthalmia: Sympathetic ophthalmia is a rare bilateral inflammation of the uveal tract that typically occurs after trauma to one eye. It does not cause a ring scotoma but can lead to other forms of vision loss due to inflammation, such as blurry vision, blind spots, or visual field loss. D. Vitreous hemorrhage: Vitreous hemorrhage is bleeding into the vitreous body of the eye, often due to conditions like diabetic retinopathy or retinal vein occlusion. It can cause visual obscuration or floaters, but ring scotomas are not typically associated with vitreous hemorrhage.

questions.text: Major site of obstruction in OAG is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Juxtacanalicular trabecular meshwork In open-angle glaucoma (OAG), the major site of obstruction to aqueous humor outflow is typically the juxtacanalicular trabecular meshwork. This part of the trabecular meshwork is located near the Schlemm's canal and is responsible for regulating the flow of aqueous humor into the canal. In OAG, increased resistance to aqueous humor outflow occurs in this area, leading to elevated intraocular pressure (IOP) and damage to the optic nerve. Incorrect Answers: A. Corneal trabecular meshwork: The corneal trabecular meshwork is part of the trabecular meshwork but not the primary site of obstruction in open-angle glaucoma. It does contribute to aqueous humor outflow, but the juxtacanalicular portion is the more important site in terms of resistance in OAG. B. Uveo-scleral trabecular meshwork: The uveoscleral pathway is an alternative route for aqueous humor outflow, which involves the uveal tissue and sclera. It is not the primary site of obstruction in open-angle glaucoma, as the main problem is usually in the trabecular meshwork itself. D. Scleral spur: The scleral spur serves as a landmark for the attachment of the trabecular meshwork but is not the site of obstruction in open-angle glaucoma. The juxtacanalicular trabecular meshwork is where the obstruction occurs.

questions.text: Pilocarpine is not used in young myopes as it causes:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Myopia Pilocarpine is a muscarinic agonist commonly used in the treatment of glaucoma. In young myopes (individuals with existing myopia), pilocarpine can exacerbate the condition by inducing accommodation (the process by which the eye adjusts to focus on near objects). The pupillary constriction (miosis) and increased accommodation caused by pilocarpine can lead to an increase in nearsightedness (myopia), worsening their refractive error. For this reason, pilocarpine is typically not recommended for young myopic individuals. Incorrect Answers: A. Folliculosis: Pilocarpine is not known to cause folliculosis (formation of lymphoid follicles in the conjunctiva). This is not a typical side effect of pilocarpine. B. Iris cyst: While pilocarpine may cause some changes in the iris, iris cysts are not a known side effect of pilocarpine. D. Uveitis: Pilocarpine is not typically associated with uveitis (inflammation of the uveal tract). However, it can cause irritation or inflammation in some individuals, but uveitis is not a common side effect.

questions.text: In a patient of bronchial asthma with open angle glaucoma, drug of choice is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Betaxolol In a patient with bronchial asthma and open-angle glaucoma, the drug of choice for managing glaucoma would be betaxolol. Betaxolol is a cardioselective beta-blocker, meaning it primarily affects beta-1 receptors in the heart, with minimal effects on beta-2 receptors in the lungs. This makes it safer for use in patients with asthma because it has a lower risk of causing bronchoconstriction, which is a major concern with non-selective beta-blockers like timolol. Incorrect Answers: A. Pilocarpine: Pilocarpine is a muscarinic agonist that constricts the pupil and increases aqueous humor outflow. While it can be used in the treatment of glaucoma, it can increase bronchoconstriction and exacerbate asthma, so it is not ideal for asthma patients. B. Timolol: Timolol is a non-selective beta-blocker that lowers intraocular pressure (IOP) by reducing aqueous humor production. However, because it blocks both beta-1 and beta-2 receptors, it can potentially cause bronchoconstriction and worsen asthma symptoms. Therefore, it is not recommended for patients with asthma. C. Ipratropium bromide: Ipratropium bromide is an anticholinergic used for managing asthma, specifically to relax the smooth muscles in the airways. However, it is not used for treating glaucoma, and it does not affect aqueous humor production or outflow, so it is not relevant in this case.

questions.text: Anterior chamber is deep in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Congenital glaucoma In congenital glaucoma, the anterior chamber is typically deep due to impaired aqueous humor outflow. This leads to elevated intraocular pressure (IOP), which causes buphthalmos (enlargement of the eyeball) and can also contribute to the enlargement of the cornea. Despite the high IOP, the anterior chamber may remain deep, especially in the early stages before significant optic nerve damage occurs. Incorrect Answers: A. Microcornea: Microcornea refers to an abnormally small cornea, which is often associated with a shallow anterior chamber. This can predispose to angle-closure glaucoma, not a deep anterior chamber. B. Hypermetropia (farsightedness): In hypermetropia, the anterior chamber can be somewhat shallow, particularly in individuals with high hypermetropia. A shallow anterior chamber is more common in hypermetropia than a deep one. D. Anterior synechiae: Anterior synechiae refers to adhesions between the iris and the corneal endothelium. These adhesions can lead to a shallow anterior chamber and angle-closure glaucoma, not a deep anterior chamber.

questions.text: Commonest symptom of infantile glaucoma is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Watering of the eyes The most common symptom of infantile glaucoma (also called congenital glaucoma) is watering of the eyes (epiphora). This occurs because the impaired drainage of aqueous humor leads to increased intraocular pressure (IOP), which in turn causes the lacrimal system to be affected, resulting in tearing. Other symptoms like photophobia, pain, and nystagmus may also occur but are less common than watering. Incorrect Answers: A. Photophobia: Photophobia (sensitivity to light) is a common symptom in glaucoma, but in infantile glaucoma, watering of the eyes tends to be the most frequent presenting symptom. B. Pain: Pain is often absent in the early stages of infantile glaucoma, but as the condition worsens or if left untreated, pain may develop due to elevated IOP and corneal edema. However, watering of the eyes is more typical. D. Nystagmus: Nystagmus (involuntary eye movements) can occur in severe cases of glaucoma, especially if optic nerve damage occurs due to prolonged elevated IOP. However, it is not as common as watering of the eyes in the early stages of infantile glaucoma.

questions.text: Inverse glaucoma is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Spherophakia Inverse glaucoma, also known as malignant glaucoma, is a type of secondary glaucoma where there is increased intraocular pressure (IOP) due to misdirection of aqueous humor. In spherophakia, which is a condition where the lens is smaller and more spherical than normal, there is a risk of the lens causing angle-closure or pupillary block, leading to this form of glaucoma. The abnormal lens shape or position can block the outflow of aqueous humor, resulting in inverse glaucoma. Incorrect Answers: A. Complicated cataract: Complicated cataract refers to cataracts that occur secondary to other ocular conditions or trauma. Although cataracts can cause changes in the anterior segment, they are not typically associated with inverse glaucoma, which primarily involves the lens in conditions like spherophakia. C. Pigmentary glaucoma: Pigmentary glaucoma is caused by the dispersion of pigment from the iris, which obstructs the trabecular meshwork. It does not cause inverse glaucoma, which involves abnormal aqueous humor dynamics rather than pigmentary dispersion. D. Glaucoma capsulare: Glaucoma capsulare refers to elevated IOP resulting from capsular block during cataract surgery. It involves trabecular meshwork obstruction due to the accumulation of material within the eye, but it is not considered inverse glaucoma, which involves misdirected aqueous humor flow.

questions.text: Essential feature of glaucoma is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Optic neuropathy The essential feature of glaucoma is optic neuropathy, which is damage to the optic nerve. This damage typically occurs due to elevated intraocular pressure (IOP), but the defining characteristic of glaucoma is the progressive loss of optic nerve fibers, leading to visual field loss. Glaucoma is primarily a nerve disease and is characterized by gradual damage to the optic nerve head, leading to permanent vision loss if untreated. Incorrect Answers: B. Raised intraocular pressure: Raised intraocular pressure (IOP) is a major risk factor for glaucoma, but it is not always present in every case. Some patients with normal-tension glaucoma (NTG) can develop optic neuropathy without elevated IOP. Thus, raised IOP is not the defining feature of glaucoma. C. Reduced vision: While reduced vision can result from glaucoma due to optic nerve damage, it is not the defining feature. In the early stages of glaucoma, vision may remain normal until significant optic nerve damage occurs. D. Painful: Glaucoma is typically a painless condition, especially in open-angle glaucoma, which is the most common form. Pain is usually a feature of acute angle-closure glaucoma, but it is not a universal symptom of all types of glaucoma.

questions.text: Optic disc changes of open angle glaucoma are all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Snow banking In open-angle glaucoma (OAG), the optic disc changes are due to progressive optic nerve damage caused by elevated intraocular pressure (IOP). The typical changes observed in the optic disc include: Incorrect options: A. Cupping of disc: Cupping of the optic disc is a hallmark feature of glaucomatous optic neuropathy. It refers to the deepening of the physiological cup in the optic disc, usually with a larger cup-to-disc ratio, due to the loss of optic nerve fibers. B. Vertically oval cup: A vertically oval cup is another typical change in open-angle glaucoma. It is often seen when the damage to the optic nerve fibers is asymmetric, leading to a vertical elongation of the optic cup. D. Bayonetting sign: The bayonetting sign is a characteristic finding in glaucoma, where there is a kinking or bending of the retinal blood vessels at the disc margin, often due to the loss of retinal nerve fibers.

questions.text: Antiglaucoma drug that causes drowsiness
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Brimonidine Brimonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used to reduce intraocular pressure (IOP) in glaucoma patients. One of its known side effects is drowsiness or sedation. This occurs because brimonidine acts on the central nervous system (CNS), and its systemic absorption can cause CNS effects like drowsiness, fatigue, and sometimes even a dry mouth. Although these side effects are generally mild, they are more commonly observed with brimonidine compared to other glaucoma medications. Incorrect Answers: A. Pilocarpine: Pilocarpine is a muscarinic agonist that causes pupil constriction and increases aqueous humor outflow. Its common side effects include eye irritation, headache, and blurred vision, but drowsiness is not typically associated with pilocarpine. C. Betaxolol: Betaxolol is a beta-blocker used in glaucoma to lower IOP. While beta-blockers can cause fatigue in some people, drowsiness is not a common side effect of betaxolol. Additionally, betaxolol is cardioselective, meaning it affects beta-1 receptors more than beta-2 receptors, which reduces the likelihood of CNS side effects. D. Prostaglandin analogues: Prostaglandin analogues (e.g., latanoprost, bimatoprost) work by increasing aqueous humor outflow through the uveoscleral pathway. Their side effects typically include eye redness, eyelash growth, and iris pigmentation, but drowsiness is not a known side effect.

questions.text: Choice of treatment of neovascular glaucoma is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Panretinal photocoagulation Neovascular glaucoma (NVG) is a form of secondary glaucoma that is characterized by the formation of abnormal blood vessels on the iris and the angle of the anterior chamber, which obstruct the outflow of aqueous humor, leading to increased intraocular pressure (IOP). The primary cause of NVG is retinal ischemia, which stimulates the production of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), leading to neovascularization. The treatment of choice for NVG is panretinal photocoagulation (PRP). PRP is used to treat the underlying retinal ischemia by using laser to create multiple small burns in the retina, thereby reducing ischemic areas and the release of VEGF. This can help to reduce or eliminate the neovascularization and lower IOP. Incorrect Answers: B. Glaucoma Drainage Device (GDD): While GDDs (such as the Ahmed valve) are sometimes used in NVG when medical therapy and laser treatment fail, they are not the first-line treatment. They are typically used in cases of refractory NVG or when surgery is needed to control IOP after laser treatment. C. Trabeculectomy: Trabeculectomy is a surgical procedure to create a new drainage pathway for aqueous humor in glaucoma patients. However, it is not as effective in NVG due to the fibrosis and scar tissue formation around the drainage site, and the presence of neovascularization often makes the procedure less successful. D. Prostaglandin analogues: Prostaglandin analogues (such as latanoprost) are used to reduce IOP by increasing aqueous humor outflow. However, they do not treat the underlying cause of NVG (retinal ischemia and neovascularization) and are not the first-line treatment for NVG.

questions.text: Antiglaucoma drug that increases the trabecular outflow
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Pilocarpine Pilocarpine is a muscarinic agonist that works by stimulating the parasympathetic nervous system, which causes pupillary constriction (miosis). This miosis opens up the trabecular meshwork, allowing for increased aqueous humor outflow through the conventional trabecular pathway. As a result, pilocarpine is effective in lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) in open-angle glaucoma and angle-closure glaucoma by enhancing aqueous humor drainage. Incorrect Answers: A. Betaxolol: Betaxolol is a beta-blocker that primarily works by reducing aqueous humor production rather than affecting outflow. It decreases IOP by lowering the production of aqueous humor from the ciliary body. C. Brimonidine: Brimonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist that lowers IOP by reducing aqueous humor production and increasing uveoscleral outflow. While it has some effect on outflow, its primary mechanism is not through the trabecular meshwork. D. Latanoprost: Latanoprost is a prostaglandin analog that increases IOP reduction by enhancing uveoscleral outflow, not the trabecular meshwork outflow. It works by improving the drainage of aqueous humor through the uveoscleral pathway.

questions.text: Most common secondary glaucoma:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Pseudoexfoliation syndrome Pseudoexfoliation syndrome is the most common cause of secondary glaucoma. It is a condition where abnormal material (pseudoexfoliative material) is deposited on various ocular structures, including the lens, iris, and trabecular meshwork. The material can cause mechanical obstruction of the trabecular meshwork, which impedes aqueous humor outflow and leads to an increase in intraocular pressure (IOP), resulting in secondary open-angle glaucoma. Incorrect Answers: A. Pigmentary glaucoma: Pigmentary glaucoma is a type of secondary glaucoma caused by the dispersion of pigment from the posterior iris into the aqueous humor, which then accumulates in the trabecular meshwork and obstructs aqueous humor drainage. While it is a well-known secondary glaucoma, it is not as common as pseudoexfoliation syndrome. C. Neovascular glaucoma: Neovascular glaucoma is a serious form of secondary glaucoma caused by the formation of abnormal blood vessels on the iris and trabecular meshwork, usually due to retinal ischemia. While it is a devastating condition, it is less common compared to pseudoexfoliation syndrome. D. Malignant glaucoma: Malignant glaucoma (also called inverse glaucoma) is a rare and severe form of secondary glaucoma that is often associated with postoperative complications, particularly after cataract surgery. It is not as common as pseudoexfoliation syndrome.

questions.text: Antiglaucoma drug contraindicated in infants :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Brimonidine Brimonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist that reduces intraocular pressure (IOP) by decreasing aqueous humor production and increasing uveoscleral outflow. However, brimonidine is contraindicated in infants and young children due to its potential to cause central nervous system (CNS) depression. Infants are particularly sensitive to brimonidine, and it can lead to serious side effects such as lethargy, bradycardia, hypotension, and respiratory depression. Incorrect Answers: B. Latanoprost: Latanoprost is a prostaglandin analog that works by increasing the outflow of aqueous humor, primarily through the uveoscleral pathway. It is generally considered safe in children, including infants, although it should be used with caution in certain populations. C. Bimatoprost: Bimatoprost is another prostaglandin analog used to lower IOP. Like latanoprost, it works by increasing aqueous humor outflow. Bimatoprost is also used in pediatric cases, particularly for conditions like congenital glaucoma, under medical supervision. D. Timolol: Timolol is a beta-blocker that reduces IOP by decreasing aqueous humor production. It is commonly used in infants and children, but care must be taken in infants with underlying conditions like asthma or bradycardia. Timolol can be used in pediatric patients, but brimonidine is specifically contraindicated.

questions.text: Which of the following can be used for self tonometry?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Rebound tonometer Rebound tonometry is a device that can be used for self-tonometry. It is a portable, easy-to-use device that measures intraocular pressure (IOP) with minimal discomfort, and it can be used by patients themselves. The device works by emitting a small probe that briefly touches the cornea and bounces back, measuring the force required to flatten the cornea. Rebound tonometry is particularly useful for home monitoring of IOP, especially in patients with glaucoma. Incorrect Answers: A. Dynamic contour tonometer: The dynamic contour tonometer is used to measure IOP and is known for its accuracy, but it is not designed for self-use. It typically requires a trained professional to operate. B. Draeger tonometer: The Draeger tonometer is a type of applanation tonometer typically used in clinical settings. It requires an experienced practitioner to perform the test, so it is not suitable for self-tonometry. D. Perkin’s tonometer: The Perkin's tonometer is a portable version of the Goldmann tonometer used for measuring IOP. It still requires a clinician to perform the measurement, so it is not intended for self-use.

questions.text: Laser trabeculoplasty is done for-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Pseudoexfoliative glaucoma Laser trabeculoplasty is a treatment commonly used in open-angle glaucoma, including pseudoexfoliative glaucoma. Pseudoexfoliation syndrome is characterized by the deposition of abnormal fibrillar material in the anterior segment of the eye, which can lead to blockage of the trabecular meshwork and result in increased intraocular pressure (IOP). Laser trabeculoplasty is used to improve aqueous humor outflow through the trabecular meshwork, helping to lower IOP and manage the condition effectively. Incorrect Answers: A. Chronic angle-closure glaucoma: Laser trabeculoplasty is not typically used for angle-closure glaucoma because this condition is caused by physical blockage of the anterior chamber angle, not impaired outflow through the trabecular meshwork. Laser iridotomy or laser iridoplasty are the primary treatments for angle-closure glaucoma. B. Neovascular glaucoma: Neovascular glaucoma is caused by the growth of abnormal blood vessels in the iris and trabecular meshwork, often secondary to retinal ischemia. The treatment involves panretinal photocoagulation to reduce the ischemia, and surgical interventions or anti-VEGF injections, rather than laser trabeculoplasty. D. Uveitic glaucoma: Uveitic glaucoma is associated with inflammation in the eye, which can lead to increased IOP. The treatment typically focuses on controlling the inflammation (e.g., using corticosteroids or immunosuppressive drugs), and laser trabeculoplasty is not the primary treatment. Corticosteroids and anti-inflammatory therapies are more commonly used.

questions.text: which of the following topical agents cause heterochromia iridis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Latanoprost Latanoprost is a prostaglandin analog commonly used to treat open-angle glaucoma by increasing the outflow of aqueous humor and lowering intraocular pressure (IOP). One of the well-known side effects of latanoprost is heterochromia iridis, a condition where there is a permanent change in the color of the iris. This usually results in darkening of the iris in patients with lighter-colored eyes (blue or green), caused by an increase in melanin production in the iris. This effect is typically seen with long-term use of latanoprost. Incorrect Answers: B. Prednisolone: Prednisolone is a steroid used to treat inflammation in various ocular conditions. While it can increase the risk of glaucoma and affect IOP, it does not cause heterochromia iridis. C. Timolol: Timolol is a beta-blocker used to reduce aqueous humor production and lower IOP. It does not cause changes in the iris color, so it is not associated with heterochromia iridis. D. Olopatadine: Olopatadine is an antihistamine used in the treatment of allergic conjunctivitis. It does not affect the iris color and is not associated with heterochromia iridis.

questions.text: ExPress Implant is made up of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Stainless steel The ExPress implant is a glaucoma drainage device used in the surgical treatment of glaucoma, particularly in cases where other forms of treatment have failed or in refractory glaucoma. The ExPress implant is made of stainless steel, which provides the necessary durability and biocompatibility for long-term implantation within the eye. The device is designed to facilitate the outflow of aqueous humor and lower intraocular pressure (IOP) in glaucoma patients. Incorrect Answers: A. Silicone: While silicone is commonly used in some medical implants due to its flexibility and biocompatibility, the ExPress implant is specifically made of stainless steel, not silicone. B. Polypropylene: Polypropylene is a synthetic polymer used in some medical devices, but it is not the material used in the ExPress implant. D. Acrylic: Acrylic is used in intraocular lenses (IOLs) and other eye implants, but it is not used in the ExPress implant, which is made of stainless steel.

questions.text: Hajari Lal, 68 Year male was operated for cataract surgery by phacoemulcification with PC-IOL implantation. After two days he developed shallow anterior chamber with IOP of 38 mm Hg. Gonioscopic examination show 360 degree of closed anterior chamber angle. Multiple peripheral iridectomies tried could not relieve the attack, diagnosis is-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Malignant glaucoma Raised IOP in a pt. Underwent catract surgery with IOP implantation and angle closure, which could not be relieved with peripheral laser iridectomies is highly suggestive of malignant glaucoma, and rules out the pupillary block glaucoma, in which peripheral laser iridectomies relives the attack Features of Malignant glaucoma · Shallow AC · Raised IOP · Angle Closer · Patent Peripheral iridectomy · Absence of suprachoroid effusion In Phacogenic glaucoma there is reaction in anterior chamber but depth remains normal

questions.text: A patient who has a history of epilepsy and is on medication, complains of sudden painful loss of vision. On examination: corneal edema, shallow anterior chamber. IOP is 50 mm Hg. What is the cause?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Topiramate The patient is presenting with sudden painful loss of vision, corneal edema, a shallow anterior chamber, and an increased intraocular pressure (IOP) of 50 mm Hg. These signs are highly suggestive of acute angle-closure glaucoma (AACG), which can be a side effect of the antiepileptic drug topiramate. Topiramate, an anticonvulsant, is known to be associated with angle-closure glaucoma. It can cause a pupillary block, leading to a build-up of fluid in the anterior chamber, resulting in a shallow anterior chamber, increased IOP, and corneal edema. This can present as a painful loss of vision and is considered a medical emergency. Incorrect Options: A. Chlorpromazine: Chlorpromazine, an antipsychotic, can cause corneal deposits and cataracts with long-term use, but it is not typically associated with acute angle-closure glaucoma. The symptoms described in the patient are more likely due to topiramate than chlorpromazine. B. Sodium valproate: Sodium valproate is an anticonvulsant that does not typically cause acute angle-closure glaucoma. Its known side effects include weight gain, tremors, and hepatotoxicity, but it is not associated with the eye findings described in this case. D. Vigabatrin: Vigabatrin is an antiepileptic medication that is associated with visual field defects, particularly peripheral vision loss, but it does not typically cause the acute ocular symptoms of angle-closure glaucoma described in this patient.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after her husband found her unconscious on the living room floor. She does not report having experienced light-headedness, nausea, sweating, or visual disturbance before losing consciousness. Three weeks ago, she was diagnosed with open-angle glaucoma and began treatment with an antiglaucoma drug in the form of eye drops. She last used the eye drops 1 hour ago. Examination shows pupils of normal size that are reactive to light. An ECG shows sinus bradycardia. This patient is most likely undergoing treatment with which of the following drugs?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Timolol is a topical agent used in the treatment of open-angle glaucoma. It is a nonselective beta-blocker that can cause bradyarrhythmias, reduced cardiac output, and orthostatic hypotension by blocking ?1, which can lead to syncope, as seen in this patient. Although Alpha 2 receptor blockade leads to an increase in peripheral vascular resistance, the overall effect is systemic vasodilation. Other adverse effects of ß2-receptor blockade include erectile dysfunction, hyperglycemia (increased insulin resistance and decreased insulin release), weight gain, hypertriglyceridemia, bronchoconstriction, and mood changes (e.g., depression).

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman comes to the emergency department 25 minutes after the onset of severe left periorbital pain and blurred vision in the same eye. The pain began soon after she entered a theater to watch a movie. She has a headache and vomited twice on the way to the hospital. Two weeks ago, she had acute sinusitis that resolved spontaneously. She has atrial fibrillation and hypertension. Current medications include metoprolol and warfarin. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 101/min, and blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg. Visual acuity is counting fingers at 3 feet in the left eye and 20/20 in the right eye. The left eye shows conjunctival injection and edematous cornea. The left pupil is mid-dilated and irregular; it is not reactive to light. Extraocular movements are normal. Fundoscopic examination is inconclusive because of severe corneal edema. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Angle closure glaucoma This 59-year-old woman presents with severe left periorbital pain, blurred vision, headache, and vomiting shortly after entering a theater. The key clinical findings are conjunctival injection, edematous cornea, a mid-dilated, irregular pupil that is non-reactive to light, and severe corneal edema. These features are highly suggestive of acute angle-closure glaucoma (ACG), a medical emergency. Acute angle-closure glaucoma occurs when the angle between the iris and cornea is closed, leading to elevated intraocular pressure (IOP), resulting in symptoms like: Severe ocular pain (often described as periorbital or behind the eye). Blurred vision, halos around lights, and corneal edema. A mid-dilated pupil that is non-reactive to light (due to the high IOP compressing the optic nerve and affecting the pupillary reflex). Nausea and vomiting can occur due to the pain and increased IOP. The patient’s history of acute sinusitis (which can affect the sinuses close to the eye) and her hypertension and atrial fibrillation (which may increase her risk for conditions like glaucoma) are important considerations. This condition is more common in individuals with hypermetropia (farsightedness) or narrow angles, which may predispose them to angle-closure glaucoma. Incorrect Options: A. Acute iridocyclitis: Iridocyclitis (inflammation of the iris and ciliary body) can present with eye pain and visual disturbances, but it usually causes more diffuse redness of the eye and does not cause corneal edema or the pupil abnormalities seen here (mid-dilated and non-reactive). Iridocyclitis also does not typically cause the severe nausea and vomiting seen in this patient, which is more consistent with increased IOP in angle-closure glaucoma. B. Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO): CRAO is caused by blockage of the central retinal artery, leading to sudden, painless vision loss in one eye. However, it typically does not cause severe ocular pain, corneal edema, or pupil abnormalities. CRAO presents with fundoscopic findings, such as a cherry red spot in the macula, but this patient’s fundus exam was inconclusive due to corneal edema, and the symptoms of pain and vomiting are more suggestive of angle-closure glaucoma. D. Retrobulbar neuritis: Retrobulbar neuritis involves inflammation of the optic nerve behind the eye and presents with vision loss, but it typically causes pain on eye movement rather than the severe, constant pain seen in angle-closure glaucoma. Additionally, retrobulbar neuritis does not cause conjunctival injection, corneal edema, or pupil abnormalities as seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 55 year male has been diagnosed with Open angle glaucoma and is on treatment. He has been prescribed eye drops which he has been putting in his eyes for last 2 years. He visits eye opd for the concerns regarding the different colour of iris. Identify the drug which has caused this.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Latanoprost This 55-year-old male with open-angle glaucoma is concerned about color changes in his iris. The drug most likely responsible for this change is Latanoprost, a prostaglandin analogue commonly used to lower intraocular pressure in patients with glaucoma. One of the well-known side effects of Latanoprost is increased brown pigmentation of the iris. This occurs due to increased melanin production in the melanocytes of the iris. The color change is typically gradual and more noticeable in patients with lighter-colored (blue or green) eyes. The effect is generally irreversible but does not affect vision. Latanoprost works by increasing uveoscleral outflow and is widely prescribed for glaucoma because of its efficacy and convenience (once-daily dosing). However, the cosmetic effect on iris pigmentation is a known adverse effect. Incorrect Options: A. Timolol: Timolol is a beta-blocker that is also used in the treatment of glaucoma. It lowers intraocular pressure by reducing aqueous humor production. However, Timolol does not cause any change in iris color. Its side effects are typically related to systemic absorption (e.g., bradycardia, fatigue, respiratory issues) but not to iris pigmentation. B. Dorzolamide: Dorzolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that works by reducing aqueous humor production, thereby lowering intraocular pressure. Similar to Timolol, it does not cause any change in iris color. Its common side effects are related to ocular discomfort or systemic issues like bitter taste or headache, but it does not affect iris pigmentation. C. Apraclonidine: Apraclonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used to lower intraocular pressure in the treatment of glaucoma. It is generally used for short-term control of intraocular pressure, especially post-operatively, and does not cause changes in iris color. Its side effects may include dry mouth, drowsiness, or ocular irritation, but it is not associated with iris pigmentation changes.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman comes to the physician because of gradually worsening blurry vision in both eyes for 5 months. She has also had intermittent headaches for the past 2 months. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, osteoarthritis, second-degree heart block, and presbyopia. Her current medications include metformin, lisinopril, and ibuprofen. Examination shows bilateral equal and reactive pupils. The best-corrected visual acuity in each eye is 20/40. There is narrowing of her visual fields bilaterally. Fundoscopic examination shows bilateral narrowing of the outer rim of the optic nerve head and cupping of the optic disk. Intraocular pressure by applanation tonometry is 27 mm Hg in the right eye and 26 mm Hg in the left eye (N=10–21 mm Hg). Gonioscopy shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Latanoprost This 64-year-old woman presents with gradually worsening blurry vision over 5 months, intermittent headaches, and findings suggestive of glaucoma on fundoscopic examination. The key findings of bilateral narrowing of the visual fields, optic disk cupping, and elevated intraocular pressure (IOP) (27 mm Hg in the right eye and 26 mm Hg in the left eye) strongly point to open-angle glaucoma. Latanoprost, a prostaglandin analogue, is a first-line treatment for open-angle glaucoma. It works by increasing uveoscleral outflow and reducing intraocular pressure (IOP). It is typically prescribed for patients with elevated IOP to help prevent optic nerve damage and further vision loss. Latanoprost is well tolerated and can be used once daily, making it an effective treatment choice for this patient. Incorrect Options: A. Trabeculectomy: Trabeculectomy is a surgical procedure used to treat glaucoma when medical therapy is ineffective or when the disease is not controlled by medications. This patient has elevated IOP, but it is not yet clear whether she has progressive optic nerve damage or has failed medical treatment. Surgery is generally reserved for patients who do not respond to medications like prostaglandin analogs or other first-line treatments. Therefore, trabeculectomy is not indicated at this stage. B. Pilocarpine eye drops: Pilocarpine is a miotic agent that constricts the pupil and can increase aqueous humor outflow through the trabecular meshwork, lowering IOP. However, pilocarpine is typically used in acute angle-closure glaucoma to constrict the pupil and relieve pressure. It is not effective in treating open-angle glaucoma, where prostaglandin analogs (like latanoprost) are preferred. C. Timolol: Timolol is a beta-blocker that reduces aqueous humor production and lowers IOP. It is a commonly used treatment for glaucoma, but prostaglandin analogs like latanoprost are generally more effective and better tolerated than timolol for long-term management. Latanoprost has the advantage of being once-daily and more effective in lowering IOP in most patients with open-angle glaucoma.

questions.text: A 60 year old is suspected to have diminution of vision due to glaucoma. You need to make sure if it is due to glaucoma or something else. Which of the following investigation to assess fundus(retinal examination) is best:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Biomicroscopy To assess the fundus in a patient suspected of having glaucoma or other retinal diseases, biomicroscopy (also known as slit-lamp examination) is the most effective method. It allows for a detailed examination of the anterior segment, including the optic nerve head, which is critical in diagnosing glaucoma. The use of a slit-lamp with a fundus lens provides a magnified view of the retina and optic disc, helping the clinician assess any optic disc cupping, nerve fiber layer loss, and retinal changes associated with glaucoma. Incorrect Options: A. Biometry: Biometry is primarily used for measuring eye length (axial length) and other parameters for cataract surgery planning (e.g., IOL calculation). It does not assess the fundus or optic nerve, so it is not useful in determining whether vision loss is due to glaucoma. C. Direct ophthalmoscopy: Direct ophthalmoscopy allows for a quick and easy examination of the retina and optic disc. However, it provides a limited field of view and does not allow for detailed assessment of the optic nerve head, which is crucial in diagnosing glaucoma. The image is not as magnified or clear as what is achieved with biomicroscopy or indirect ophthalmoscopy. D. Indirect ophthalmoscopy: Indirect ophthalmoscopy offers a wider field of view and is useful for viewing the periphery of the retina. However, biomicroscopy (slit-lamp examination) is generally preferred for assessing the optic nerve head in patients with suspected glaucoma, as it provides higher magnification and more detailed visualization.
